ygData.subject: Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Jeff, Well I don t know about the exact implementations of HyperNEAT you are using (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations disabled), but in

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=gcBUmuMv0ofOVWOHkF-9-FRdLuNuhT5LIY_TjQQMlAC-kgqXfnJBKf9oJg

Hi Jeff, 

Well I don't know about the exact implementations of HyperNEAT y=
ou are 
using (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations 
disab=
led), but in principle crossover should choose genes randomly 
from both pa=
rents as it builds the offspring genome, the child. In 
HyperNEAT the cross=
over is different, there you actually do a regular 
NEAT evolution of netwo=
rks that build other networks based on the 
substrate configuration. That i=
s, you only mate and mutate the CPPNs. 
But in the case you get lots of ind=
ividuals with equal fitness, I 
guess these individuals are clones. Perhaps=
 the code frequently 
chooses the same individuals for mating? You can try =
to avoid this by 
introducing a loop in which you try candidates for a "fat=
her" that are 
not compatible with the mother, that is, when their compatib=
ility 
distance is 0.00, try again. There is another possibility, simply 
e=
very mutation disturbs the CPPN and therefore the produced network is 
chan=
ged in such a magnitude that is has no chance for survival and is 
discarde=
d. Even though there is speciation. 

Peter


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all-
> 
> Does crossover do anythi=
ng in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
> 
> PNEAT:
> If I am reading the code correctly=
, during crossover, if the 
substrates are
> the same (i.e. all links have =
the same ID), which is always the case 
in
> P-NEAT, *all* of the link valu=
es are taken from either parent1 or 
parent2.
> Isn't it more normal when c=
rossing over to take some from parent1 
and some
> from parent2? Why grab a=
ll from just one?
> 
> This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, rig=
ht? It will 
always grab
> the substrate of parent1 or the substrate of par=
ent2.  If I track 
parent and
> offspring fitness, 100% of the time the chi=
ld has the exact same 
fitness as
> one of the two parents.
> 
> On to Hype=
rNEAT:
> 
> I tracked the fitness of each parent and the resulting offsprin=
g. 
The odd
> thing is that the organisms that are crossed only (i.e. they =
are 
never
> mutated) have the *exact* same fitness of one of their parents=
 
98.88% of the
> time. In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out of 12257 tha=
t were 
crossed over
> and not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why w=
ould these new 
links
> have such a small impact? It turns out that this is=
 because nearly 
every
> time that there is an extra link that gets placed =
in the child, the 
parent
> that donated that link is also the parent whose=
 weights are being 
grabbed,
> meaning that the crossover is only copying t=
he parent (hence the 
same
> fitness). It seems to me that crossover should=
 be much more 
disruptive, no?
> 
> 
> As a final test, I did a set of hype=
rneat and pneat runs with the 
default
> 'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter =
set to .25, so 25% of orgs never 
are
> candidates for crossover. I then ra=
n experimental treatments
> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the M=
utateOnlyProbability
> parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were crossed over=
. Despite my 
comments
> above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-n=
oCross, however 
the
> difference was not tremendous (although it does seem=
 to be 
statistically
> significant). For p-neat, the reverse was true. Nev=
ertheless, this 
is not a
> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividend=
s, because if 
crossover does
> nothing most of the time, and I increase Mu=
tateOnlyProbability from 
.25 to
> 1, I have effectively raised the mutatio=
n rate (only 80% of crossed 
orgs are
> also mutated).
> 
> Are these the i=
ntended consequences of crossover, or am I missing 
something?
> 
> Cheers,=

> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> 
> jc=
lune@...
>
